I live on Amsterdam‚Äôs East side with Anja and Lemonade

Since 2016 I‚Äôve been living in Amsterdam‚Äôs Indische buurt with my partner Anja Waleson, a high school English teacher and new potter. We share a little shoebox with a petit garden. I make an effort to enjoy hobbies outside of work

Recently, Anja and I made a change to how we handle our birthdays: instead of receiving individuals gifts from friends and family, we host a mini crowdfunding to raise money for a specific goal. In December, after three decades of longing, I finally bought a piano. I am in love with it, and I‚Äôve been practicing technique and songs ever since.

I‚Äôm looking forward to the local outdoor pool opening up again so I can go for my 6:30AM morning swims. I‚Äôve missed swimming plenty over the winter, and it might be smart to find a good indoor pool for the later months of 2023. For now, I‚Äôm pleased to know that Amsterdam‚Äôs finest outdoor pool is in our own backyard.

I‚Äôm joining medtech scaleup Gerimedica in May

I hinted at this in recent weeknotes, but I‚Äôm very pleased to say I‚Äôm starting a new career adventure. After 2.5 years with the wonderful team of Leeruniek I‚Äôm joining Gerimedica in May. I knew when I joined Leeruniek that I‚Äôd eventually make the jump to medical technology, and I can‚Äôt think of a better landing spot than Gerimedica.

At Leeruniek, I fell deeply in love with impact-driven product development. My new manager at Gerimedica told me during my hiring process that their goal is to help people spend less time in their product, and I absolutely love that. I‚Äôm looking forward to contributing what I can.

I‚Äôm mentoring again

After a hiatus, I‚Äôm pleased to be back on the mentoring market. With 16 years of professional experience, I‚Äôve found that my stories, many of which I had always deemed irrelevant to the world, can be of help to other people in the IT industry, specifically UX designers and researchers and product managers. If you‚Äôd like to book a session with me, you may do so via ADPList.

I‚Äôm doing my best to accept the ebb and flow of life

One of the thinking traps in which I routinely fall is the one where ‚ÄúY can happen when X is completed‚Äù. We make a plan and God laughs. I‚Äôve found that meditation helps me break this cycle. I‚Äôve been devoting time daily to a meditation session. It‚Äôs becoming easier to remember that even 10 minutes of practice is worthwhile, even when I keep comparing myself to monks on some Tibetan mountain.

I‚Äôm learnming how to be kind to my neurodivergent brain

Through trial and error, I‚Äôm finding ways to help myself best learn and deliver. One thing that‚Äôs been helpful in this regard is accepting my tendency to think top-down rather than bottom-up. It‚Äôs marvellous to see how much of the world assumes a bottom-up approach to learning, communicating, and creating. YouTuber Elizabeth Filips has been of great help on this journey.
